question: Prayer is obligatory in all circumstances, especially in times of distress. - Even if war were chosen, prayer should precede it.  Therefore, making prayer sound merely conditional conflicts with its mandatory nature

Regarding what the Rambam z"l wrote (in Hilchos Yesodei HaTorah, Chapter 7) that one who believes solely based on signs (otot) has doubt in his heart, because it's possible that the sign was performed through sorcery or magic. Even with Moshe Rabbeinu a"h, Israel did not believe in him because of the signs he performed, etc. Rather, [they believed in him because he was] a person whom we knew was worthy of prophecy, etc., and who walked in the ways of prophecy with holiness and separation [from worldly matters]. Only afterward, when he performed a sign or wonder, is there a mitzvah to listen to him.

This is similar to the Torah's command to judge based on two kosher witnesses, even though it's possible they testified falsely. Since they are considered kosher in our eyes, we maintain their presumption of kashrus, etc. "Man sees with the eyes, but Hashem sees into the heart."

It is thus clear that one cannot rely on signs and wonders alone, unless the person is established as a great man, wise and worthy of prophecy. Only then should one believe in him in conjunction with the signs. Even though this isn't absolute proof, and people might err in considering someone righteous - for man only sees with his eyes - since the Torah commanded us to believe in such a case, and the Torah wouldn't lead us astray, this mitzvah serves as a guarantee that with these two signs (being worthy and performing wonders), a prophet will always be verified. Heaven will not allow him to deceive in this manner with these two signs, for if this weren't the case, no prophet could ever be verified.

As the Ramban z"l wrote (in Parshas Shemos) regarding what our Sages said in the Midrash that it was a tradition that any redeemer who comes and speaks of a double remembrance (pekidah kefulah) is a true redeemer. The Ramban z"l asked: How did Israel know to believe Moshe? Perhaps Moshe had heard this tradition just like they had? He answered that they certainly received from Yosef, who heard from Yaakov, that the first one who would come and speak in this language would be the redeemer, and it was known before the Holy One, Blessed be He, that no person would come and deceive them with this, and thus He assured them. Heaven does not allow deception in such matters.

Similarly with Yosef, once they verified through seeing his milah (circumcision) that he was a tzaddik (righteous person), they then believed in the sign of his speech when he spoke in Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). Also, his speech was visible to the physical sense of sight. However, one cannot believe in a sign alone, as it's possible to perform signs through kishuf (sorcery) and magic, as the Rambam z"l wrote.

Therefore, there is no proof from here that two intermediate simanim (signs) are effective everywhere like a distinct siman muvhak (clear sign), as it's possible they wouldn't be effective elsewhere. Here they only believed him because of two signs: since they saw he was a tzaddik, they believed him based on the signs, similar to how the Torah commands us to believe based on a chazakah (presumption) if someone is established as great and wise.

In this way, we have assurance that a navi (prophet) will always be verified, and from Heaven they won't allow him to lie in this manner. Therefore, the tribes relied on these two signs. Furthermore, here the signs were clear and distinct - there was clear proof of his righteousness from showing them he was circumcised, and they saw the Divine Presence resting upon him. From seeing his language, it became clear to them that his mouth and heart were aligned, and he wouldn't change his speech even for the sake of Heaven, as mentioned above.

Therefore, since the signs were clear and distinct, the tribes relied upon them. However, there is no proof from here regarding signs that aren't distinct, and this doesn't pose a difficulty to those who disagree with the Masas Binyamin mentioned above.

2) Further in the Midrash on "Vayigash eilav Yehudah vayomer [And Judah approached him and said]" etc.: Rabbi Yehudah says it was an approach for war, as it is said etc.; Rabbi Nechemiah says it was an approach for appeasement etc.; The Rabbanan (Sages) say it was an approach for prayer etc.; Rabbi Elazar says he explained to them (that Yehudah was explaining his words to Yosef and said to him): "If I come for war, if I come for appeasement, if I come for prayer." Until here.

It is worthy to understand that while what he said about "if for war" and "if for appeasement" makes sense, as he made it conditional and uncertain - that if war is desired, he would fight with him, and if appeasement is desired, he would enter into appeasement with him - but regarding what he said "if for prayer," how could he make prayer conditional and uncertain? Prayer is obligatory in all circumstances. And even according to the Ramban z"l who holds that prayer is rabbinical, nevertheless in times of distress it is a Torah obligation. If so, even if he comes for war, he would be obligated to precede it with prayer, for there is no greater distress than war. So why did he make prayer conditional and uncertain?

The words of the Midrash mentioned above (in the previous drush) can be explained: "And Judah approached him" - Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, Rabbi Nechemia says it was an approach for appeasement, etc., and the Rabbis say it was an approach for prayer - and all these are the words of the living G-d. All these aspects were included in his words.

As we explained regarding Joseph's words, besides their simple meaning, the inner meaning of the words contained hints to lofty and hidden matters. Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.

And with this we can understand the connection of the words of the Midrash Tanchuma mentioned above: "And he sent Judah before him," and similarly [regarding] Zion, "Behold, I send My messenger." Rashi explains [this means] to eliminate the wicked ones and clear the path from the wicked. Therefore, he prepared a Beis Talmud that would have no trace of avodah zarah, from which hora'ah would emanate, and through this, Israel would have survival even in galus (exile) and merit the future redemption. "And Yehudah approached him, etc., 'and let not your anger burn against your servant, for you are like Pharaoh.' Rashi explains, based on the Midrash, 'You will eventually be stricken with tzara'as (leprosy) just as Pharaoh was stricken because of my grandmother Sarah, who was detained for one night, etc.' Another explanation: 'for you are like Pharaoh' means if you provoke me, I will kill you and your master.

There are difficulties with both interpretations. It should have said 'for you will be like Pharaoh,' rather than 'for you are like Pharaoh' with two comparative כ's (kafs). Additionally, according to the first interpretation, what force does this warning have - that he will eventually be stricken with tzara'as like Pharaoh was through my grandmother Sarah? In that case, Pharaoh was struck immediately through her word, as Rashi explains. Therefore, when he sees that the punishment doesn't match Pharaoh's immediate punishment, he won't fear the future warning either. How could he warn him with something that isn't comparable?

According to the second interpretation - 'if you provoke me, I will kill you' - it's difficult to understand why he made the killing conditional on provocation. matched_passages.passage: והנה איתא בספה"ק דכשצדיק פוגע ברשע צריך לשמור מאוד שלא יהיה נפגם מראיית פניו, ורק אם יש לו זכותים ניצול ממנו, וכאן הרי ידעו כולם כי בנימין מעודו צדיק גמור הוא, ואיך זה פתאום נכשל בדבר הגניבה, אע"כ בוודאי הוא ע"ו שנתעכב לילה אחד בשכונת רשע, או כל הדבר לא היה ולא נברא, והוא רק עלילה מצד המושל, וז"ש יהודה וכי זו הוא שימת עין שאמרת לשום עינך עליו, היינו כו בודאי מה שאירע לו דבר הגניבה, הוא רק מכוחך מה ששמת עינך עליו וזהו הכוונה בטענת שימת עון, ועכ"פ יוצא מזה כו אתה אינך ירא אלקים ואיך אמרת את האלקים ואני ירא, ועכשיו נוכחנו לדעת שדברת שקר, וכמוך כפרעה שעשאך ימלך אע"פ שהיית עבד ובנימוסי מצרים כתוב שאין עבד מולך וז"ש מה פרעה גוזר ואינו מקיים וכו' ולפי' השני א"ל אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדונך, ויובן עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל שהשבטים הרגו לאנשי שכם, לפי שלא הושיבו דיינין כי בני נח מצווין על הדינין למנות דיינים בכל פלך ופלך יעיי"ש, וכאן שהי' יוסף משנה למלך ורצה לעכב את בנימין לעבד בלי משפע, ובעלילת שקר, ע"כ אמר לו יהודה כי ע"פ הדין אתה מחוייב מיתה עם אדונך אם תעשה הדבר הזה בלו משפט, כי אתה מצווה לעשות משפט אמת בלא עוולה.

Here, everyone knew that Binyamin was always a complete tzaddik, so how did he suddenly stumble with theft? Therefore, it must either be because he stayed one night in the neighborhood of a rasha, or the entire incident never happened and was merely a false accusation by the ruler.

This is what Yehudah meant when he said, "Is this the 'watching over' that you promised when you said you would keep your eye on him?" Meaning, the theft incident occurred only because of your influence when you set your eyes upon him - this is the meaning of the claim about "setting guilt." In any case, this proves that you do not fear God, so how could you say "I fear God"? Now we know you spoke falsely, and you are like Pharaoh who made you king even though you were a slave, and according to Egyptian law, a slave cannot become king.

This is what is meant by "Just as Pharaoh decrees and doesn't fulfill..." And according to the second interpretation, he said to him, "If you provoke me, I will kill you and your master." This can be understood based on what the Rambam wrote, that the tribes killed the people of Shechem because they didn't establish judges, as Bnei Noach (Noahides) are commanded regarding laws to appoint judges in every district.

Here, since Yosef was viceroy and wanted to keep Binyamin as a slave without justice and with false accusations, Yehudah told him that according to the law, both you and your master deserve death if you do this thing without justice, for you are commanded to execute true justice without wrongdoing.

matched_passages.passage: ובאמת שכדעת הרמב"ם ז"ל מבואר בדברי חכז"ל (במד"ר פרשת בא) משכו וקחו לכם צאן הה"ד (תהלים צ"ב) יבושו כל עובדי פסל. בשעה שאמר הקב"ה למשה לשחוט הפסח, א"ל משה רבון העולם הדבר הזה האיך אני יכול לעשות, אי אתה יודע שהצאן אלהיהן של מצרים הן, שנאמר הן נזבח את תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלניג א"ל הקב"ה חייך אין ישראל יוצאין מכאן עד שישחטו אלהי מצרים לעיניהם, שאודיע להם שאין אלהי העכו"ם כלום וכו' ע"כ, מבואר כדעת הרמב"ם ז"ל שהטעם לשחיטת קרבן פסח הוא להודיע שאין ממש בע"ז כלום, ודחיית הרמב"ן ז"ל לא קשה, דהרי מצינו שאמר הכתוב כו לא יוכלון המצרים לאכול את העברים לחם כי תועבה הוא למצרים, ופי' בתרגום אונקלוס ארי בעירא דמצראי דחלין לי' עבראי אכלין, הרי שלא חרה אפם של המצריים על אכילת תועבותם עד כדי שיסקלו אותם בשבילה, רק שלא יכלו לאכול עם העברים כי תועבה הוא להם, משא"כ כשצוה הקב"ה לשחוט הטלה לשם קרבן פסח, כתיב הן נזבח וגו' ולא וסקלונו, מבואר שהוא ביטול יותר גדול אצליהם מאם שוחטין ואוכלין מהם לשובע, וסרה קושית הרמב"ן ז"ל שיותר תתרפא המחלה באכלינו מהם לשובע, עכ"פ מכל אלו הראיות מבואר כשיטת הרמב"ם ז"ל.

In truth, according to the opinion of the Rambam z"l, it is explained in the words of our Sages (Midrash Rabbah, Parshat Bo) regarding "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," as it is written (Psalms 92), "All workers of idols shall be ashamed." When HaKadosh Baruch Hu told Moshe to slaughter the Pesach offering, Moshe said to Him, "Master of the Universe, how can I do this thing? Don't You know that sheep are the gods of Egypt, as it is said 'Will we not be stoned if we sacrifice the abomination of Egypt before their eyes?'" HaKadosh Baruch Hu replied, "By your life, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes, so that I may make known to them that the gods of idolaters are nothing, etc."

This clearly supports the Rambam's z"l view that the reason for slaughtering the Pesach offering was to demonstrate that there is no substance to avodah zarah (idolatry). The Ramban's z"l objection is not difficult, for we find that Scripture states, "The Egyptians could not eat bread with the Hebrews, for it is an abomination to Egypt." Onkelos translates this as "because the animals that the Egyptians worship, the Hebrews eat." This shows that the Egyptians' anger over eating their sacred animals was not so severe that they would stone them for it; rather, they simply couldn't eat with the Hebrews because it was an abomination to them.

However, when HaKadosh Baruch Hu commanded to slaughter the lamb as a Pesach offering, it states "Will we not sacrifice... and they will stone us," showing that this was a greater nullification in their eyes than merely slaughtering and eating for sustenance. This resolves the Ramban's z"l question about how the illness would be better cured by eating them for satisfaction. In any case, from all these proofs, the Rambam's z"l position is clearly supported.

In any case, it is clear that the holy tribes recognized that Yosef was a holy and wise man, knowledgeable in all types of wisdom, but they did not know that he was Yosef. It was necessary that this fact remain hidden from them, as is known. This is why Yosef said to them "Bring him down to me, and I will set my eyes upon him," meaning that he would deal with him according to the laws of the Torah. He also hinted to them that he would draw down the miraculous power of Purim, when there was a renewed acceptance of the Torah, as our Sages said "they accepted it again in the days of Achashverosh."

This is what he meant by "I will set my eyes upon him" - that he would channel the power of Torah, which is hinted at in the word "asima" (I will set), through the gezeirah shavah (textual comparison) with "These are the ordinances that you shall set (tasim) before them," as explained in the Midrash. Yehudah understood his intention in saying "I will set my eyes upon him," and therefore came to him with the argument: "Is this the 'setting' you spoke of? The matter has been turned into blindness."

This is based on what our Sages said (Shabbos 88): "For those who approach it from the right, it is a potion of life; for those who approach it from the left, it is a potion of death." The Torah itself becomes a deadly poison if one does not follow it in the way of truth. This is what is meant by "the matter you spoke of has been turned to blindness" - that the Torah you learn and transmit to others has been turned to blindness and became a deadly poison since you are not conducting yourself in the true way of the holy Torah. For in our law it is written "if he has nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft," but this one has the means to pay. Let us explain the verse (Chronicles I, 22) where David said to his son Solomon: "I had it in my heart to build a house for the Name of Hashem my G-d. But the word of Hashem came to me, saying: 'You have shed much blood and fought great battles; you shall not build a house for My Name because you have shed much blood on the earth before Me.'" The Radak explains that David was not punished for this bloodshed, as his intention was to eliminate the wicked who would breach [the security of] Israel, etc. However, since he was involved in extensive bloodshed, he was prevented from building the Beis HaMikdash (Holy Temple), which represents peace and atonement for sin. This is similar to the prohibition against using iron on the altar and in the Beis HaMikdash, as iron is used to make weapons of killing and should not be used to make instruments of peace.

However, in the Pesikta d'Rav Kahana (in the section about Chanukah), it states: "A psalm for the dedication of the House, by David." Come and see that Solomon built the House, yet it was called by David's name. This is because David was worthy to build it, but due to one matter he did not build it. Although he intended to build it, Nathan the Prophet came and told him, "You shall not build the House, because you have shed much blood on the earth." When David heard this, he became afraid and said, "I have been disqualified from building the Beis HaMikdash." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to David, "Do not fear. By your life, these [bloodsheds] are before Me like [the blood of] a deer or a hart... All the blood you shed was before Me like sacrifices, as it is written 'because you have shed much blood on the earth before Me.'"

David asked, "If so, why can't I build it?" The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied, "Because if you build it, it will stand permanently and never be destroyed." David said, "But that would be good!" The Holy One, Blessed be He, responded, "It is revealed and known before Me that they [Israel] will sin in the future, and I will vent My wrath upon it [the Temple] and destroy it, and [thereby] Israel will be saved."

This seems to require explanation, as there appears to be a contradiction between the beginning and end. It starts by saying David couldn't build the Temple because he shed much blood, but concludes that it was because of David's great spiritual level that enemies would not have power over his handiwork. It's also difficult because this latter reason isn't mentioned in the verse at all, which only mentions "because you have shed much blood on the earth before Me," implying that preventing David from building the Beis HaMikdash was a form of punishment.

One can further explain based on the holy Ramban's words on the verse "And Israel journeyed with all that he had, and came to Beer-sheba, and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac." This verse contains a secret, etc. The text specifies "sacrifices" to inform us that these were not burnt offerings like his forefathers offered. For Abraham offered burnt offerings, and our Rabbis said that the children of Noah did not offer peace offerings but burnt offerings, and regarding Noah it explicitly states "and he offered burnt offerings on the altar." But Jacob, out of fear of Hashem, offered peace offerings (shelamim) to harmonize all the divine attributes, as they interpreted that shelamim brings peace (shalom) to the world.

Although he hints at lofty secrets in his words, we must also understand them according to their simple meaning. The explanation is that each tzaddik serves Hashem through a different attribute and aspect. Thus, Yehudah and Yosef each had different spiritual attributes, as our Sages alluded to when they said "this one is an ox and this one is a lion." Yaakov Avinu wanted to make peace between these two attributes, therefore when he went to Egypt and sent Yehudah ahead - yesterday the lion and ox were fighting and now he sends him to him - he offered peace offerings to harmonize the attributes of Yehudah and Yosef.

Similarly, one can say that when Yehudah approached Yosef, he recognized that Yosef's attribute was different from his own, and he wanted to make peace between the two attributes. For this reason, he offered peace offerings to harmonize their attributes. Remarkably, the holy Zohar states that the same unification that was achieved through the sacrifices was accomplished then by Yehudah and Yosef. Following our approach, one could say that Yehudah actually offered a sacrifice when he approached Yosef, thereby seeking to make peace between the two attributes. This explains the words of the Midrash: Abba Kohen Bardela said, "Woe to us from the Day of Judgment, woe to us from the Day of Rebuke, etc." Joseph was the youngest of the tribes, and they could not withstand his rebuke, as it is written "and his brothers could not answer him because they were frightened before him." At first glance, what does rebuke have to do with this? Joseph didn't actually rebuke them; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them at that time. So how do we learn about rebuke from here? Also, why is this comparison necessary, and what is the relevance of this analogy?

Following our approach, we can explain that even though there will be great merit for Israel on the Day of Judgment and Rebuke, as the subjugation of exile and the hiding of [God's] face (hester panim) were the causes of our negligence in serving Hashem, and had we merited the revelation of the light of His Divine Presence (Shechinah), we certainly would have been more attached to Him and to the holy Torah. Nevertheless, there will still be great shame because through our actions we caused this terrible concealment and the removal of His Divine Presence from Israel.

This explains the kal vachomer (a fortiori argument): Joseph didn't rebuke his brothers; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them. Even in the act itself, they had no sin, as explained in the Midrashim that it was to their merit and is remembered forever. Also, it was necessary to fulfill the decree of "Know with certainty." Still, his brothers could not answer him and were frightened before him for the above reason - because they caused the removal of the Divine Presence. How much more so, what will we answer on the Day of Judgment?

Therefore, he never needed the segulah of remembering the day of death, and thus did not recite Krias Shema when he appeared before his father. For his way had always been to overcome the yetzer hara through Torah and Krias Shema.

This explains well the verse "And Yisrael said to Yosef, 'I will die this time.'" Until now, he needed to remember the day of death at all times, but now "I will only die once, when my day comes and my end arrives." And as long as I shall live, I will not need the remembrance of the day of death, but I can overcome the yetzer hara through the simcha shel mitzvah via Torah and Krias Shema. And he explained the reason: "after I have seen your face, that you are still alive," and I can serve Hashem with joy.

Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And regarding what is written in the Midrash "do not withhold yourselves from divrei Torah (words of Torah)," it means they should not refrain from mentioning the divrei Torah that Yosef told them when he accompanied them, as it is written "and he sent his brothers and they went" - the word "sending" here implies accompanying, as a person should not depart from his fellow except with a matter of halacha (Jewish law). Certainly, he accompanied them with divrei Torah. If their anger was still in place, they would necessarily refrain from mentioning his teachings. Therefore, he told them "do not become agitated on the way," meaning, "set aside the anger you have towards me." Consequently, "do not withhold yourselves from the divrei Torah that I told you, and do not engage in [new] divrei Torah," meaning, to innovate new insights, for deep analysis is not appropriate [at this time].

According to this, both the Gemara and the Midrash intended the same thing, and each one speaks truth, and everything goes to one place, just that they were expressed with different wording. But both intended to convey that Yosef HaTzaddik (the righteous) warned them to remember his teachings, and this would help protect them on their journey. Both derived this from the verse "do not become agitated on the way."
